As a youth going in to the adult division of a first aid charity I was discouraged by an adult from having the HBV vaccine because in their eyes it wasn't an issue. My response was, that it only takes one blood exposure to be infected and the danger to the liver were serious. I was 16.

Perhaps most importantly, after completing an HBV vaccine series, protective responses occur in the vast majority of people. Before we had the universal policy, we could explain about half of infant HBV infections by transmission during childbirth. The other half? We don't know.

where there is a high risk of HBV infection, suggesting that they were selected for. And yet, they are still a minor proportion of overall variants, and before vaccination campaigns began, they still had a high level of endemic burden of HBV. The resistance mutations did not eliminate the virus.

except for some very rare genetic conditions. The receptor that enables HBV infection (NTCP) is present in basically everyone, and even people with 2 copies of variants that are shown to promote resistance have been infected and developed chronic HBV. Those mutations,are enrichedin populations...

Recently, I've been asked whether every baby actually needs HBV vaccination, largely with the implication that doing this is ""one size fits all,"" and that's not a good approach. Implicit in this assumption is the idea that every individual's physiology is so unique that it demands unique care.

The reality is that while everyone's specific health situation may be different, physiology from person to person is much more similar than it is different. The properties of the infant immune system that render them so susceptible to chronic HBV infection exist essentially in all infants...

And it doesn‚Äôt end there! Nuclear land usage AND waste production both come in lower than any other electricity source, whether renewable or fossil fuel.

Nuclear is available 24/7, regardless of weather. Its lifetime greenhouse gas emissions are the lowest of all major sources, and it is also one of the safest per unit of energy produced. Its fuel efficiency per gram is literally off the charts compared to the big 3 fossil fuels.

He refuses to learn ONE chemistry fundamental yet the US Senate enabled his grift as the position of US health leadership. His Minamata convention video is the same tactic he used during a measles outbreak in Samoa, when his anti-vaccine lies killed dozens of children. 9/

RFK Jr pretends thimerosal‚Äôs ethylmercury cation is the same as methylmercury. This is chemically illiterate & dangerously ignorant. Even though he has been corrected about this for over two decades, he continues to profit off this lie. 8/
Thimerosal doesn‚Äôt cause autism. Or other neurological issues. Or any adverse effects at the minuscule quantities used in vaccines. It makes vaccines safe. 7/

Ethylmercury (rather, thimerosal) prevents harmful contamination of multi-dose vaccines once opened. Thimerosal makes vaccines accessible & safe for billions of people globally. Thimerosal has been in use as an antimicrobial for 100 years. 6/

Claiming ETHYLmercury is the same as METHYLmercury would be like saying ethanol is the same as methanol. One is found in your favorite cocktail, one is incredibly toxic at small exposures. You understand those aren‚Äôt the same, right? Same chemistry rules apply here. 5/

Thimerosal is a salt: in chemistry, an ionic compound that dissociates in water. The positive ion is ethylmercury, C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÖHg‚Å∫. Ethylmercury is *not* mercury. It‚Äôs also *not* methylmercury, a compound that accumulates in our environment & can cause toxicity. 4/

Or that air, a mixture, is the same as pure nitrogen gas. You understand these aren‚Äôt the same, right? If anti-vaccine activists applied their own ‚Äúlogic,‚Äù they‚Äôd tell people that table salt explodes in water. Funny how they ignore chemistry to profit off their lies. 3/

That‚Äôs why table salt, sodium chloride (NaCl), doesn‚Äôt explode when you put it in water, while SODIUM explodes in water. Claiming thimerosal is mercury is like saying water (H2O) is the same as hydrogen gas (H2). Or glucose (C6H12O6) is the same as diamonds (C atoms). 2/

Thimerosal has formula C9H9HgNaO2S. It is not mercury. The systematic name for thimerosal is Ethyl(2-mercaptobenzoato-(2-)-O,S) mercurate(1-) sodium. Chemicals aren‚Äôt the sum of their parts. Chemical bonds change everything about behavior. 1/

""He told MPs: ‚ÄúIn financing public infrastructure I remain committed to the use of public-private partnership where it delivers value for the taxpayer and genuinely transfers risk to the private sector. ‚ÄúBut there is compelling evidence that the Private Finance Initiative does neither.‚Äù""

""Due to the huge number of PFI schemes created under the previous Labour government, there is a ****wealth of evidence as to the drawbacks of the model*****. In 2018, then-chancellor Philip Hammond announced PFI schemes were being abolished.""

This is neoliberal nonsense because the economy is not a household budget. ""By far the biggest advantage of PFI schemes however, and one which made them so popular under the Blair Labour government, is that the borrowing is accounted for differently and kept off the government books.""

Proponents of PFI ‚Äì who are harder and harder to find ‚Äì also claim that it encourages investment by offering reliable returns. The government with it's financial power can demand far better for the treasury.

Carillion In 2018, Carillion collapsed. The UK‚Äôs second largest construction firm, it had a network of PFI contracts worth billions. Prof Iqbal Khadaroo and lecturer Ekililu Salifu ‚Äì wrote at the the time: ‚ÄúThe NHS, defence, education, energy, and prisons have all been left exposed by its collapse.‚Äù

Safety hazards, sewage leaks and falling ceilings are major risks after decades of underinvestment and the legacy of PFI 'Capital crisis‚Äô and ‚Äòtoxic‚Äô legacy of PFI. Analysis of HMRC data found that PFI, costs an extortionate amount. For just ¬£13bn of investment, equals an ¬£80bn bill.

2 trusts terminated PFI contracts, reducing their operational expenditure. It is an expensive process, with penalties being paid to break the contract. Another trust went bankrupt over the cost of its two PFI hospitals; the finance costs were much higher than the average, pushing up the deficit.

Uni of Manchester research examines affordability issues relating to hospital infrastructure. Whilst PFI charges, only represent around 1.4% of total NHS spend, at local trust level they can create affordability issues. Some trusts have reduced costs by taking actions on their PFI contracts.

Not value for money. Cripplingly expensive. No need for more. Clearly, demonstrably, a massive waste of money that wouldn't cost enormous sums of interest as well. Which you'd know if you'd read the post. Perhaps tell me the restrictions that exist in PFI contracts and we can evaluate 'daft'.

If the same money were invested directly into expanding NHS ward space, staff, and theatres - or even more importantly social care capacity to help discharge patients safely - the long-term impact would be far greater. Instead, we‚Äôre paying for short term relief instead of building resilience.

And the cost is also relevant - these contracts are funded by the same NHS budget that‚Äôs forcing trusts to find massive CIPs, implement hiring freezes, and in some cases consider redundancies. Which is less efficiency and more displacement.

And ultimately this IS capacity taken out of the NHS system. When an NHS consultant performs a surgery at an independent hospital, that‚Äôs one less session available in their trust. It‚Äôs relieving pressure one way while raising it in another.

And while the government described this as ‚Äúspare capacity,‚Äù it‚Äôs not free capacity. It‚Äôs paid-for capacity, at a premium, from the same pool of NHS consultants and anaesthetists who already work in overstretched trusts. We‚Äôre not conjuring new staff out of thin air - we‚Äôre moving them around.

It is absolutely good news when patients get seen faster - I won‚Äôt dispute that. BUT - before we celebrate too loudly, it is worth asking what this latest ‚Äúuse of independent sector capacity‚Äù actually means for the NHS itself and whether it actual fixes any of the fundamentals.
